items.title: ASX edges higher ahead of GDP data | Silver breaks new record
items.summary: The Australian share market has closed higher ahead of tomorrow’s key GDP data, where a strong economic growth figure could further complicate the Reserve Bank’s interest rate decision next week. Plus, silver’s rally continues with the precious metal breaking above US$58 an ounce overnight. For more, Stephanie Youssef spoke with MPC Markets CEO Mark Gardner.

items.title: 'I wish I was a dog in Australia': Muhammad's story as UN probes immigration detention
items.summary: Australia's immigration detention regime is under United Nations scrutiny this week. The U-N Working Group on Arbitrary Detention is examining how the country deprives people of their liberty — from prisons to offshore detention facilities. And for people like Muhammad, who spent six years in detention, this review is one that's long overdue.

items.title: Rhetoric and 'gunboat' diplomacy: Is Trump pushing the US toward war with Venezuela?
items.summary: United States President Donald Trump has threatened a ground invasion of Venezuela to disrupt what he claims is a vast drug-trafficking network. The U-S military has already deployed thousands of troops and dozens of warships to the Caribbean as a U-S air campaign that has killed at least 83 people continues. But how likely is an all-out war with their South American neighbour, really?

This comes as French President Emmanuel Macron says this may be a turning point for Europe’s security, as Ukraine doubles down on long-term defence with a large French fighter-jet deal.

items.title: Rate cuts? What rate cuts - Home prices have eaten them alive
items.summary: New data reveals that surging home prices have wiped away the benefits of three interest rate cuts to new buyers. Rent prices are also rising in every capital city, prompting more and more Australians to form larger households or move back to their family home. The rising prices have left economists predicting a possible rate hike in 2026.

items.title: 'At risk of losing everything': The frontline rangers protecting the Great Barrier Reef
items.summary: Indigenous rangers from the Great Barrier Reef are learning coral spawning techniques in one of the largest reef restoration trials to date. The pilot program involves rangers working in the reefs off Queensland's Keppel Islands, which were hit hard by last year's mass coral bleaching event.

items.title: More details emerge about interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS
items.summary: There's been widespread and growing speculation that interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS is an alien craft. But scientists have debunked the claims. New observations from NASA and South Africa’s MeerKAT telescope confirm it is a natural, volatile-rich comet showing textbook outgassing, hydroxyl radio emissions and expected orbital shifts. Far from extraterrestrial engineering, 3I/ATLAS offers a rare window into the deep past, likely originating in a star system billions of years older than our own.

items.title: All about Australia's biggest environmental reforms this century
items.summary: After five years of review, the government has struck a deal with the Greens to pass the largest reforms to Australia’s environmental laws in 26 years, which includes new environmental standards, protections for native forests, and the effective end of fast-tracked approvals for coal and gas projects. Despite these wins, the deal faces criticism from environmental experts.

items.summary: The United States has amended its peace plan for Ukraine, reducing it to 19 points and opening a dual diplomatic track with Moscow and Kyiv. But the new plan is stirring anxiety that Donald Trump might be willing to push Ukraine to sign a peace deal heavily tilted towards Russia.

items.title: Controversy over Melbourne event appearing to celebrate Israeli pager operation
items.summary: Lebanese and Jewish groups have condemned a planned event in Melbourne that appears to celebrate last year's Israeli pager operation in Lebanon, which killed dozens and injured thousands more. The event run by the group called Lions of Zion has been labelled 'disgraceful' - but organisers say they are celebrating what they describe as one of the most ingenious military operations in history.

items.title: Senate erupts as Pauline Hanson wears burqa, gets suspended
items.summary: The Australian Senate descended into chaos as One Nation leader Pauline Hanson wore a black burqa into the chamber, prompting immediate condemnation from Muslim Senators and a forceful intervention by Foreign Minister Penny Wong. Following the rejection of her motion to ban the burqa, Ms. Hanson's stunt, which she claimed was about "protecting national security," was decried as racist and disrespectful to people of faith, ultimately leading to her suspension from the Senate.

items.title: "Total impunity": Israeli settler lawlessness in the West Bank destroys livelihoods of Palestinian farmers
items.summary: For Palestinian-Australian winemaker Sari Kassis, the reality of farming in the West Bank is one of constant physical and psychological danger. With settler violence surging in the West Bank, this year's harvest has seen a record number of Israeli attacks on farms and properties.

items.title: ‘Everywhere is not safe’: Nigeria faces spate of mass abductions
items.summary: A wave of mass abductions in Nigeria have triggered school closures across the country with anxiety, panic and anger spreading. One of these attacks saw over 300 school children kidnapped from a Catholic secondary school in the worst single kidnapping incident in five years.

However, the Ukrainian president remains wary of being pushed into accepting a deal on Russian terms, while Ukrainians seem unwilling to meet their neighbour's demands.

The notable absence of President Donald Trump has raised questions the role of the United States, in a changing world order.

items.title: Rental squeeze intensifies: Perth now Australia’s least affordable city
items.summary: Despite interest rates stabilising, rental stress remains unchanged across Australia. In many capital cities, households are still handing over almost a third of their income just to keep a roof over their heads. And once again, Perth has it the worst. The nation’s least affordable capital has slipped even further — recording another four per cent drop in affordability on top of last year’s record low.

items.title: Fair Work shake-up: gig workers secure pay rise and protection
items.summary: In a landmark agreement hailed as world-leading, the Transport Workers Union, Uber, and DoorDash have put forward a minimum standards deal for Australian gig workers to the Fair Work Commission today. This major reform guarantees food delivery riders a 25% wage increase, injury insurance, and protection from unfair algorithmic dismissal, fundamentally changing a commission-based system that workers say left them making virtually no money.

items.title: 'Adult’ pressures hit hard as UNICEF warns teens are losing hope

Mental health issues and anxiety around 'adult' challenges like housing and money are key drivers of declining wellbeing. For marginalised children and teens, these kind of pressures are felt even more acutely.

items.title: 'Extraordinary rise': Australia's housing affordability hits worst levels yet
items.summary: In Sydney's eastern suburbs, it would take 35 years for an average wage earner to save up a 20 per cent deposit for a median-priced house.

items.title: Not just a 'women's issue': New fertility guidelines bring men into focus
items.summary: Australian researchers have unveiled the first male infertility guidelines, standardising care and recognising men's significant role in fertility challenges.

items.title: ASX bounces back as BHP walks away from AA
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Raymond Chan from Morgans Financial Limited about the day's sharemarket action including a recovery on the ASX as the chance of a US rate cut in December swings back up and why BHP walked away from a second crack at Anglo American.

items.title: Bureau of Meteorology weathers website storm
items.summary: The Bureau of Meteorology's controversial website redesign carries a staggering 96 million dollar price tag. The cost blowout has drawn sharp criticism from both government ministers and the opposition. Federal Environment Minister Murray Watt has expressed deep concern over the massive expenditure, while Nationals Leader David Littleproud warns the public that the exorbitant cost will further erode trust in the agency.

items.title: 'Women have choice': Anne Aly says Pauline Hanson's burqa stunt 'unacceptable'
items.summary: Multiculturalism Minister Anne Aly says Pauline Hanson aims to divide with burqa stunt, arguing women "have choice".

items.title: 'Women have choice': Anne Aly says Pauline Hanson's burqa stunt 'unacceptable'
items.summary: Multiculturalism Minister Anne Aly says Pauline Hanson aims to divide with burqa stunt, arguing women "have choice".

items.title: Ashwini's biggest concerns now will cost the country 'billions' in the future
items.summary: Children are growing more anxious and worried as they age, a new report says. Failing to address their concerns is costly.

items.title: SBS News in Easy English 24 November 2025
items.summary: A five minute bulletin for English language learners

items.title: COP30 deal keeps humanity 'in the fight for a liveable planet': UN chief
items.summary: Delegates to the COP30 summit in Brazil have reached an agreement to address still rising global emissions. The deal increases money to countries hit by climate change, but contains no explicit fossil fuel plan. The agreement has mollified some - and horrified others.

items.title: What Black Friday sales shopping does to your brain, and how to stay in control
items.summary: Black Friday feels like a celebration of savings, but it is also a masterclass in behavioural and brain science.

items.title: The human cost of renewables: Why Australia should build solar here
items.summary: With the renewable energy transition underway in Australia, the higher than expected uptake of solar panels has human rights groups concerned about links to Uyghur forced labour in the supply chain. As Australia looks into developing its own solar panel industry, rights groups say government and industry should work to ensure the clean energy transition isn't at the cost of freedom.

items.title: What we know about Israel's latest strike on Hezbollah in Beirut
items.summary: The strike came a week before Pope Leo was set to land in Lebanon on his first foreign trip.

items.title: What we know about Israel's latest strike on Hezbollah in Beirut
items.summary: The strike came a week before Pope Leo was set to land in Lebanon on his first foreign trip.

items.title: A Russian 'wish list' or path to peace? The evolving plan to end Russia's war on Ukraine
items.summary: Donald Trump has given Ukraine until Thursday to accept the US proposal to end Russia's war. But European leaders have now stepped in with different plans — more palatable for Ukraine.

items.title: 'It's just impossible': The rental crisis pushing working families to the brink
items.summary: Rental stress is at its worst levels on record, with renters in one city now spending nearly a third of their income on housing.

items.title: 'No way out': Vietnam flooding death toll reaches 90 as search continues for missing
items.summary: Relentless rain has lashed south-central Vietnam since late October and popular holiday destinations have been hit by several rounds of flooding.

items.title: A 'massive' number of wildlife die on our roads. Experts say protections are falling far short
items.summary: Wildlife-safe road features remain largely optional, a “nice-to-have, not need-to-have”, the author of new research warns.

items.title: Trump signals room to negotiate Ukraine peace deal, as Rubio insists plan is US-led
items.summary: The US president had given Ukraine until Thursday to approve the plan, which requires it to cede territory to Russia, cut its army and pledge never to join NATO.

items.title: How a major MAGA figure went from Trump devotee to calling quits on Congress
items.summary: Marjorie Taylor Greene announced her resignation this weekend after a dramatic falling out with the president that was months in the making.

items.title: Fresh wave of Israeli airstrikes kills more than 20 people in Gaza
items.summary: Israel and Hamas have accused each other of violating the tenuous ceasefire in Gaza multiple times over the last six weeks.

items.title: New names added to migration Welcome Wall at National Maritime Museum
items.summary: Two panels have been unveiled at Australia's National Maritime Museum to honour a new group of migrant families. Museum Director and CEO Ms Daryl Karp and Home Affairs Minister Tony Burke say the Monument is a celebration of the long history of migrants who have shaped modern Australia.

items.title: INTERVIEW: Associate Professor Bassina Farbenblum
items.summary: As thousands of international students prepare to take summer holiday jobs, Associate Professor Bassina Farbenblum, an expert on migrants' rights from the University of New South Wales, warns that more is needed to protect students from wage theft and abuse. She says Australia has a ‘pervasive problem’ with workplace exploitation of international students and those on temporary visas. Dr Farbenblum is speaking to SBS’s Sandra Fulloon.

items.title: Underground struggles: Illegal miners risk death in Morocco's forgotten coal town
items.summary: In one of Morocco's impoverished coal towns, illegal miners continue to risk their lives to make ends meet. In an exclusive sit-down interview with SBS News, a photojournalist has shared the harsh realities he witnessed of the miners in Jerada. Ahead of the International Mining Congress in Morocco, experts are calling for better health and safety regulations to be implemented in the country.

items.title: 'Isolation and shame': Australians are avoiding perinatal mental health support, new research reveals
items.summary: Around one in four Australians are failing to seek support when experiencing perinatal mental health issues. Experts say the data released by the Gidget Foundation highlights a lack of awareness around signs and symptoms, and ongoing stigma around the issue.

items.title: 'You don't have the freedom to leave': The human cost of Australia's solar boom
items.summary: As Australia's uptake of solar panels booms, human rights groups have raised alarm about links to Uyghur forced labour in the supply chain.

items.title: Some world leaders make decisions while chronically sleep-deprived. Should they?
items.summary: Sleep deprivation undermines our ability to think clearly. So what should we make of leaders who say they run on just a few hours?

items.title: The two words missing from the world's most important climate conference agreement
items.summary: An agreement on climate action has been reached at COP30 in Brazil — but not everyone is happy with the final result.

items.title: Owed $10,000, Khoa was left stranded on a farm with no food or funds. He's not alone
items.summary: Despite recent reforms, exploitation of migrant workers remains a serious issue in Australia, experts say.

items.title: Leadership spills and policy reversals: How healthy is our democracy?
items.summary: With the abandonment of its net-zero policies, and leadership spills in two of Australia's largest states, the Coalition is undergoing a period of major upheaval. So what does that mean for a Westminster democracy which analysts say depends on two different political positions to succeed.

items.title: ‘No food, no money’: Khoa was abandoned and owed $10,000 in unpaid wages. He’s not alone
items.summary: As the academic year ends, thousands of international students are signing on for holiday work. But if things go wrong, experts warn that few understand their legal entitlements or how to recover unpaid wages.

items.title: 'The odds are against us': Why some Australian homeowners may never upgrade
items.summary: The property ladder has changed since the COVID-19 pandemic. Data shows some homeowners may never get the chance to upgrade.

items.title: US rate fears trump Nvidia's better than expected result
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Lochlan Halliday from Morningstar to find out what spooked investors despite Nvidia's better than expected profit and if it's likely to last.

items.title: SBS News in Easy English 21 November 2025
items.summary: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

items.title: Where Kunzang's from there's no ocean. Now in Darwin, he's worried about the cyclone
items.summary: The man from Bhutan has only been in the NT for three months, and says he doesn't know what to expect from Fina.

items.title: 'That courageous girl': Matildas coach's support for Mary Fowler after alleged racism experience
items.summary: Matildas star Mary Fowler has alleged she experienced racism during her time with French club Montpellier, which has denied the allegations.

items.title: Warning issued over 'quick cash' scam targeting international students
items.summary: An urgent warning has been issued to international students departing Australia to not sell their bank accounts and ID to criminals. The Australian Federal Police says students are offered 'quick cash' - but accepting it could see them indelibly linked to crime networks.

items.title: Rules on this common travel item change today. Here’s why they’re risky
items.summary: Rules around power banks are increasingly tightening after a string of incidents. How do you know if yours is safe?

items.title: Fire forces evacuation of Brazil climate conference with negotiations still short of a deal
items.summary: The fire has now been brought under control and 13 people have been treated for smoke inhalation, officials said.

items.title: Why government debt matters: spoiler, it’s not just Monopoly money
items.summary: We know government debt is around $1 trillion, we've heard it's bad for younger generations -- but we don't really know what any of it means. This week, Elfy and Rania chat with Professor Richard Holden from the University of New South Wales about government debt and why it matters.

items.title: PNG questions 'what planet' the Opposition is on, after it ditches net zero support
items.summary: Papua New Guinea's foreign minister has said the Opposition's position on climate change "won't do them any favours, or us any favours".

items.title: 'Daily challenge': The hidden cost of living crisis affecting families
items.summary: A food relief charity says it has so much demand it's forced to turn schools away.

items.title: 'Can't have it all': Australia abandons bid for COP31 climate summit
items.summary: The federal government has abruptly abandoned its bid to host the United Nations climate conference next year, conceding Turkiye will oversee the COP31. The Pacific countries and environmental activists have criticised the federal government's failure to bring the event to Adelaide.

items.title: Nvidia goes off the charts as ASX recovers
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Ben Clark from TMS Private Wealth to go through AI chip giant Nvidia's record results and whether this is the turning point the market was looking for.

items.title: Trump, Epstein & the Saudi Crown Prince, and autocrat karaoke
items.summary: Trump wipes the slate clean of murder for Mohammed bin Salman because ‘things happen’. The Epstein files move a big step closer to being released and what it’s like reporting on the ground in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. Plus, the comment that sent China-Japan relations plummeting.

items.title: 'Completely emptied': Human rights report alleges Israeli war crimes in West Bank camps
items.summary: Human Rights Watch reports 32,000 Palestinians were forcibly displaced from West Bank camps in 2025.

items.title: Bicycle kicks and tears: Here are the teams who have qualified for the 2026 FIFA World Cup
items.summary: In the November qualifying rounds, 14 additional teams, including some surprising names, secured their places for the 2026 FIFA World Cup.

items.title: SBS News in Easy English 20 November 2025
items.summary: A five minute bulletin for English language learners

items.title: Meta admits there may be mistakes as it brings teenager social media ban forward
items.summary: Meta warns some teenagers may "mistakenly lose access" as it rushes to implement new social media restrictions.

items.title: 'Pushing its own agenda': PNG's top diplomat lashes Türkiye after Australia withdraws COP31 bid
items.summary: Australia has abandoned its bid to host COP31 in Adelaide, meaning the event will be held in Türkiye.

items.title: At least 25 Palestinians killed in Israeli airstrikes across Gaza, medics say
items.summary: Wednesday's strikes were among the deadliest in the territory since the ceasefire came into force.

items.title: Indonesia’s drowning island takes historic climate case to court
items.summary: Indonesia is home to more than 17,000 islands, but its smallest are highly vulnerable to the impacts of climate change. The tiny community of Pari Island is facing multiple climate-induced threats, including to its entire existence.Four people on the island are now trying to launch a landmark legal case against a European cement giant over its historic carbon emissions.

items.title: 'The worst we've seen': The type of job that's getting harder to find in Australia
items.summary: A new report has painted a grim picture of Australia's employment system, calling on the federal government to urgently intervene.

items.title: Calls for superannuation protections as some retirees could lose up to $205,000
items.summary: A new report is calling on the federal government to include protections for retirees when it comes to super performance testing.

items.title: 'Sheer terror': Palestinians arrive in Australia after 'mysterious' South Africa flight saga
items.summary: A small group of Palestinians with Australian visas were onboard a flight to South Africa making headlines around the world, and have since made their way to Australia.

items.title: Chris Minns on hospital funding row: we can't all be wrong
items.summary: State premiers have come together for an urgent meeting, as tensions rise over reaching a new public hospital funding deal with the federal government. A new report from the Grattan Institute also finds Australia's hospitals are wasting more than $1 billion a year on avoidable spending.

items.title: Eyes on Nvidia & wages rise above inflation
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Matt Sherwood from Perpetual about the day's market action including why Nvidia's quarterly results tomorrow may be a turning point; plus Paula Gadsby from EY goes through the latest wages data and what it means for interest rates.

items.title: Curaçao makes World Cup history after completing fairytale qualification campaign
items.summary: Curaçao has replaced Iceland as the smallest nation by population to qualify for a World Cup.

items.title: Flattery, fighter jets and a trillion dollar pledge as Saudi Crown Prince meets Trump
items.summary: Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, returning to the White House for the first time since the murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi, has met President Donald Trump at the Oval Office. The two leaders discussed a number of matters including Saudi Arabia investing a trillion US dollars in America for AI Chips, F-35 fighter jets, the Khashoggi assassination and Gaza's reconstruction.

items.title: Socceroos lose to Colombia in New York as World Cup preparations continue
items.summary: Australia took on Colombia in an international friendly in New York, following their loss against Venezuela on Saturday.

items.title: SBS News in Easy English 19 November 2025
items.summary: A five minute bulletin for English language learners

items.title: 'Nobody should face this hatred': NSW moves to crack down on Nazi symbols after march
items.summary: The NSW government is moving to crack down on Nazi symbols, giving police new powers to act against public displays.

items.title: US Congress votes to force release of Epstein files
items.summary: The US Congress has voted overwhelmingly to release the Department of Justice files on disgraced financier and convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein. After months of political pressure to release the files, survivors of Epstein's abuse say they hope this can lead to some justice.

items.title: 'Things happened': Donald Trump defends Saudi crown prince over journalist's murder
items.summary: The US president gave the de facto ruler of Saudi Arabia a lavish welcome to the White House.

items.title: Campaign targets schoolies over alcohol dangers while overseas
items.summary: As thousands of teenagers celebrate the end of Year 12, they're being reminded of the risks that come with drinking alcohol, especially overseas.The parents and friends of methanol-poisoning victims Bianca Jones and Holly Bowles have joined a new safety push, encouraging young travellers to make safer choices.

items.title: $60bn wiped from ASX & scams rise ahead of Black Friday sales
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with David Lane from Ord Minnett about why the ASX200 had its second worst day of the year as $60bn is wiped off the value of the local sharemarket; plus Angelica Waite discusses the rise of scams ahead of Black Friday with the ACCC's Catriona Lowe.

items.title: 'They hate modern Australia': South African neo-Nazi detained after visa cancelled
items.summary: Matthew Gruter was one of 60 black-clad demonstrators who were allowed to assemble outside NSW parliament and yell Hitler youth chants on 8 November.
